Meshing¶

class meshing.GetBasin(di, basin=None)[source]¶

This class contains functions to return a contour corresponding to the perimeter of various basins in Antarctica and Greenland. The libraries of basins are drawn from ICESat data, and posted here:

http://icesat4.gsfc.nasa.gov/cryo_data/ant_grn_drainage_systems.php

INPUTS:
di :
an instance of a DataInput obect (see above) needed for the projection function
basin:
basin number. If left as None, the program will prompt you to pick a basin

TODO: Now working to extend the domain beyond the present day ice margin for the purpose of increasing the stability of dynamic runs. Additionally, there appear to be some stability issues when running the MCB algorithm, but these are not consistent; some domains work, others do not. The hope is that extension of the domain will help here too.

Originally written by Aaron St. George, updated by Evan Cummings

Extends a 2d contour out from points labeled in self.edge by a distance <r> (radius) in all directions. NOTE: this only works for greenland.

intersection(other)[source]¶

Take the geometric intersection of current coordinates with <other>. Used primarily to replace the edge with something from a different (better) data set.

NOTE: it’s probably better to extend the boundary before taking the intersection.

class meshing.MeshExtruder(mesh)[source]¶

Due to extreme bugginess in the gmsh extrusion utilities, this class extrudes a 2D mesh footprint in the z direction in an arbitrary number of layers. Its primary purpose is to facilitate mesh generation for the ice sheet model VarGlaS. Method based on HOW TO SUBDIVIDE PYRAMIDS, PRISMS AND HEXAHEDRA INTO TETRAHEDRA by Dompierre et al.

Written by Douglas Brinkerhoff 14.01.25

generate a mesh.

add_box(10000, 260000, 620000, -1080000, -710100, 0, 0)

create_2D_mesh(outfile)[source]¶

create the 2D mesh to file <outfile>.msh.

create_contour(var, zero_cntr, skip_pts)[source]¶

Create a contour of the data field with index <var> of <dd> provided at initialization. <zero_cntr> is the value of <var> to contour, <skip_pts> is the number of points to skip in the contour, needed to prevent overlap.

eliminate_intersections(dist=10)[source]¶

Eliminate intersecting boundary elements. <dist> is an integer specifiying how far forward to look to eliminate intersections. If any intersections are found, this method is called recursively until none are found.

extend_edge(r)[source]¶

Extends a 2d contour out from points labeled in self.edge by a distance <r> (radius) in all directions.

extrude(h, n_layers)[source]¶

Extrude the mesh <h> units with <n_layers> number of layers.

finish(field)[source]¶

figure out background field and close the .geo file.

intersection(new_contour)[source]¶

Take the geometric intersection of current coordinates with <new_contour>. Used primarily to replace the edge with something from a different (better) data set.

load_contour(name)[source]¶

Loads the contour from the ouput directory self.direc named name set to self.longest_cont.

Parameters:name (string) – name of the file to load the contour.
plot_contour()[source]¶

Plot the contour created with the “create_contour” method.

remove_skip_points(skip_pts)[source]¶

remove every other <skip_pts> node from the contour.

restart()[source]¶

clear all contents from the .geo file.

save_contour(name)[source]¶

Saves the current contour self.longest_cont to the ouput directory self.direc named name.

Parameters:name (string) – name of the file to save the contour as.
set_contour(cont_array)[source]¶

This is an alternative to the create_contour method that allows you to manually specify contour points. Inputs:

cont_array : A numpy array of contour points
(i.e. array([[1,2],[3,4],…]))
transform_contour(di)[source]¶

Transforms the coordinates of the contour to DataInput object <di>’s projection coordinates.

write_argus_contour()[source]¶

write the contour created with create_contour() to the .exp file within the directory self.direc/self.fn.

write_gmsh_contour(lc=100000, boundary_extend=True)[source]¶

write the contour created with create_contour() to the .geo file with mesh spacing lc. If boundary_extend is true, the spacing in the interior of the domain will be the same as the distance between nodes on the contour.

class meshing.linear_attractor(spline, f, f_max, l_min, l_max, inv=True)[source]¶

Create an attractor object which refines with min and max cell radius \(l_{min}\), \(l_{max}\) over data field \(f\). The \(f_{max}\) parameter specifies a max value for which to apply the minimum cell size such that if \(f_i\) is less than \(f_{max}\), the cell size in this region will be \(l_{max}\). If inv = True the object refines on the inverse of the data field \(f\).

\[\begin{split}h_i = \begin{cases} l_{min}, & f_i > f_{max} \\ l_{max}, & f_i < f_{max} \\ f_i, & otherwise \\ \end{cases}\end{split}\]

Args:

spline:the iterpolator which is evaluated at x- and y-coordinates
f:the array being interpolated
f_max:maximum value of f for l_max and l_min
l_min:minimum cell size
l_max:maximum cell size
inv:boolean, invert f for attraction
op(x, y, z, entity)[source]¶

Method which evaluates this linear attractor.

Args:

x:the x-coordinate
y:the y-coordinate
z:the z-coordinate (not used)
entity:not used

Returns:

lc:characteristic radius for a given cell at (x,y)
class meshing.max_field(f_list)[source]¶

class meshing.min_field(f_list)[source]¶

Return the minimum of a list of attactor operator fields <f_list>.
